HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 14, 1926.

PI DELTA EPSILON
RETURNS -CHARTER
The Pi Delta Epsilon
Honorary Literary Fraternity has turned back its charter to the National Fraternity. •The decision was reached by the unanimous vote of
the members of the fraternity at a meeting held last
Wednesday.
The reason for this action,
according to Henry Turnbull, president, was because
the purposes of the fraternity are adequately fulfilled
by other Honorary Fraternities at Hopkins.
Opportunity will be given
those that are eligible to join
this year, for their own benefit.

IN PHILADELPHIA
TOMORROW
Both Teams Will Face Off With Many

Up until the Wednesday before
the Onondaga game, Penn, who
will play Hopkins in Philadelphia
tomorrow, was looked upon as
sort of a rest before the Maryland
game. Last Wednesday a week
ago Penn defeated Stephens 8-2.

CAPS AGAIN
The hearts- of upperclassmen will no doubt be warmed by
the decision of the Student Council to again include the wearing of caps in the freshman regulations for next year. Once
more, after the lapse of a year, the campus will be brightened,
and the youthful appearance of the freshmen enhanced, by the
distinctive black and blue head pieces.
But there are other reasons, beside these purely artistic
ones, which make the return to caps a wise policy. Freshmen
regulations, it is generally admitted, are desirable; and to us
the wearing of caps is the most important provision of the
regulations. The whole aim of the rules which apply each fall
to the incoming class is- to impress upon them that they are
no longer all-important high School seniors, but members of
the lowest class in college. The cap goes a long way toward
doing it. It never serves to increase its wearer's sense of selfimportance or savior Mire; in fact it was designed to make him
look as ridiculous as, possible, and the University colors are
thrown in for good measure.
In addition, the caps' serve to develop class solidarity by
providing a token by which all that are under the yoke of regulations may recognize their fellow sufferers. And incidently
they are valuable in sitigling out to the sophomore his prey.
_
From what we have said, one might think that we regarded
the cap as some kind of a cure-all which may be applied to
every failing peculiar to freshmen. That, of course, is absurd.
Only associations with undergraduates and professors, over a
long period of time can mould a newcomer into a university
man, or more particularly, a Hopkins man. But regulations
have their place, and the cap is an important item. We sincerely hope that President Goodnow will approve the regulations submitted-by- the -Student Council:

A -cord dance- is being inno
vated at the University of California, and the entrance requirements
for the men will be corduroy trousers, the only restriction being
that these must be clean. The
purpose of the affair is to induce
the men to wash their cords, as
some have not washed them since
the beginning of school last fall.
The only restriction for the girls
is that they wear sport clothes.

Students at Oklahoma now have
under discussion the advisability
of adopting the Baylor College
method of evading the no-auto
edict. When the Baylor faculty
ruled that there should be no nocturnal auto-riding, gloom was cast
upon the campus, until one. night
a creative genius brought an oldtime means of locomotion known
as the "horse-and-buggy" around
to his girl friend's door, thus inaugurating a now popular custom.

The Interfraternity Board is to be congratulated upon their
unusual achievement of amicably drawing up a rushing agreement before the final examinations-,begin. Although this lays
to rest some of the problems of next year, it far from settles
all of them. The newly made reputation for efficiency in drawing up the agreement must be maintained by the adoption of
better methods of enforcing it.
Probably on account of their very restrictive character,
at least we hope there is some logical way to explain it, past
rushing agreements have never been entirely lived up to. Since
violations of the spirit of rules have been practically universal,
the occasional breaches of the letter have been treated lightly.
In some colleges violations of the rushing agreement are
looked upon in the same light as violations of the honor system.
Consequently offenses occur rarely, and when they do, both the
fraternity and the individual involved suffer serious consequences.
Possibly the agreement this year is a little easier to keep.
But whether it is easy or hard, it is up to the fraternities bound
by it to regard it as a gentleman's agreement, and it is up to
the Board to provide punishment such that if violations do
- occur, they will not easily be forgotten.

overcame this lead in their half
of the inning when their entire
team batted around and scored
six runs.

To mountain
climbers about
to cross a plateau
a thought for seniors about to
set forth on the world's biggest climb—
their careers.
Educators tell us that mental growth, if
diagrammed, would show a succession of
mountains and plateaus. Progress in industry, too, has its plateau—the periods
when you seem merely to be marking time.
But is it time lost? Older graduates, now
executives in industry; say "No." They recall this as really a chance to find one's self,
to get one's second wind for the next climb
ahead.
And they recall the fact that this whole
journey, up the mountain and across the plain,
is a great adventure with each man blazing
his own trail, working out his own individuality in the various technical and commercial
activities of modern business.

PI DELTA EPSILON
RETURNS -CHARTER
The Pi Delta Epsilon
Honorary Literary Fraternity has turned back its charter to the National Fraternity. •The decision was reached by the unanimous vote of
the members of the fraternity at a meeting held last
Wednesday.
The reason for this action,
according to Henry Turnbull, president, was because
the purposes of the fraternity are adequately fulfilled
by other Honorary Fraternities at Hopkins.
Opportunity will be given
those that are eligible to join
this year, for their own benefit.

CAPS AGAIN
The hearts- of upperclassmen will no doubt be warmed by
the decision of the Student Council to again include the wearing of caps in the freshman regulations for next year. Once
more, after the lapse of a year, the campus will be brightened,
and the youthful appearance of the freshmen enhanced, by the
distinctive black and blue head pieces.
But there are other reasons, beside these purely artistic
ones, which make the return to caps a wise policy. Freshmen
regulations, it is generally admitted, are desirable; and to us
the wearing of caps is the most important provision of the
regulations. The whole aim of the rules which apply each fall
to the incoming class is- to impress upon them that they are
no longer all-important high School seniors, but members of
the lowest class in college. The cap goes a long way toward
doing it. It never serves to increase its wearer's sense of selfimportance or savior Mire; in fact it was designed to make him
look as ridiculous as, possible, and the University colors are
thrown in for good measure.
In addition, the caps' serve to develop class solidarity by
providing a token by which all that are under the yoke of regulations may recognize their fellow sufferers. And incidently
they are valuable in sitigling out to the sophomore his prey.
_
From what we have said, one might think that we regarded
the cap as some kind of a cure-all which may be applied to
every failing peculiar to freshmen. That, of course, is absurd.
Only associations with undergraduates and professors, over a
long period of time can mould a newcomer into a university
man, or more particularly, a Hopkins man. But regulations
have their place, and the cap is an important item. We sincerely hope that President Goodnow will approve the regulations submitted-by- the -Student Council:

A -cord dance- is being inno
vated at the University of California, and the entrance requirements
for the men will be corduroy trousers, the only restriction being
that these must be clean. The
purpose of the affair is to induce
the men to wash their cords, as
some have not washed them since
the beginning of school last fall.
The only restriction for the girls
is that they wear sport clothes.

Students at Oklahoma now have
under discussion the advisability
of adopting the Baylor College
method of evading the no-auto
edict. When the Baylor faculty
ruled that there should be no nocturnal auto-riding, gloom was cast
upon the campus, until one. night
a creative genius brought an oldtime means of locomotion known
as the "horse-and-buggy" around
to his girl friend's door, thus inaugurating a now popular custom.

Fi

The Interfraternity Board is to be congratulated upon their
unusual achievement of amicably drawing up a rushing agreement before the final examinations-,begin. Although this lays
to rest some of the problems of next year, it far from settles
all of them. The newly made reputation for efficiency in drawing up the agreement must be maintained by the adoption of
better methods of enforcing it.
Probably on account of their very restrictive character,
at least we hope there is some logical way to explain it, past
rushing agreements have never been entirely lived up to. Since
violations of the spirit of rules have been practically universal,
the occasional breaches of the letter have been treated lightly.
In some colleges violations of the rushing agreement are
looked upon in the same light as violations of the honor system.
Consequently offenses occur rarely, and when they do, both the
fraternity and the individual involved suffer serious consequences.
Possibly the agreement this year is a little easier to keep.
But whether it is easy or hard, it is up to the fraternities bound
by it to regard it as a gentleman's agreement, and it is up to
the Board to provide punishment such that if violations do
- occur, they will not easily be forgotten.

To mountain
climbers about
to cross a plateau
a thought for seniors about to
set forth on the world's biggest climb—
their careers.
Educators tell us that mental growth, if
diagrammed, would show a succession of
mountains and plateaus. Progress in industry, too, has its plateau—the periods
when you seem merely to be marking time.
But is it time lost? Older graduates, now
executives in industry; say "No." They recall this as really a chance to find one's self,
to get one's second wind for the next climb
ahead.
And they recall the fact that this whole
journey, up the mountain and across the plain,
is a great adventure with each man blazing
his own trail, working out his own individuality in the various technical and commercial
activities of modern business.
